question.text: The discs are rotating about their axes, normal to the discs and passing through the centres of the discs. Disc $D_1$ has $2 \mathrm{~kg}$ mass and $0.2 \mathrm{~m}$ radius and initial angular velocity of $50 \mathrm{rad} \mathrm{s}^{-1}$. Disc $\mathrm{D}_2$ has $4 \mathrm{~kg}$ mass, $0.1 \mathrm{~m}$ radius and initial angular velocity of $200 \mathrm{rad} \mathrm{s}^{-1}$. The two discs are brought in contact face to face, with their axes of rotation coincident. The final angular velocity (in rad $s^{-1}$ ) of the system is:

solution.text:
M.J. of $\mathrm{D}_1$ is $\mathrm{I}_1=\frac{\mathrm{MR}^2}{2}=\frac{2(0.2)^2}{2}$ $=0.04 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^2$ initial angular velocity of $D_1$ is $\omega_1=50 \mathrm{rad} \mathrm{S}^{-1}$ M.J of $\mathrm{D}_2$ is $\mathrm{I}_2=\frac{4 \times(0.1)^2}{2}=0.02 \mathrm{~kg} m_2$
initial angular velocity of $\mathrm{D}_2$ is $\omega_2=$ 200 and $\mathrm{S}^{-1}$. According to the law of conservation of angular moment
$$
\begin{gathered}
L_1=L_2 \\
\therefore \mathrm{I}_1 \omega_1+\mathrm{I}_2 \omega_2=\left(\mathrm{I}_1+\mathrm{I}_2\right) \\
\Rightarrow \omega=\frac{l_1 w_1+l_2 w_2}{\mathrm{I}_1+1} \\
\therefore \omega=\frac{(0.04)^2 \times 50+(0.02)^2 \times 200}{0.04+0.02} \\
=\frac{2+4}{0.06}=100 \mathrm{rads}^{-1}
\end{gathered}
$$
